element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, head of the Black Knights Warren Lewis describes moving to Memphis from his hometown in rural Mississippi and his activism around the time of the Sanitation Worker's Strike. He also expresses his frustration with the lack of interest and motivation of the late 1970s and 1980s Civil Rights movement.

element.name: none
element.field: Warren Lewis, head of the Black Knights, 1983

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Darrell Richardson, a minister, writer, and resident of the VECA neighborhood. Richardson moved to the community during the time of integration and white flight, he chose a house in a racially mixed neighborhood. He discusses the street he lives on and his relationship with his white and black neighbors. Richardson also talks about the nearby churches and their own integration process. He is also a member of VECA and talks about the organization. This interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

element.name: none

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Brad McMillan, an artist involved in the Evergreen News publication. McMillan a Rhodes College, formerly Southwestern, alumni created the layout and illustrations for the newsletter. McMillan talks about the culture of media and the importance of providing information. He mentions how crucial the newsletter was for the neighborhood, especially during a time of integration. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with Charles Dinkins, he describes how organizations like the National Business League and the Federal Chamber of Commerce helped to fund African American business owners, create jobs for the economically disadvantaged, and otherwise improve economic development in Memphis's African American communites. He also describes how he believes various Civil Rights groups affect community development and economic growth. ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with D'Army Bailey, an attorney, retired circuit court judge, civil rights activist, author, and film actor from Memphis, Tennessee. In this interview Bailey talks about his activism as a college student, his relationship with CORE (Congress of Racial Equality) and NSM (Northern Student Movement), at a PWI and an HBCU. Bailey also discusses his time practicing law in a racially divided society. The interview was conducted in 1979 at his home on Monticello.ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, native Memphian Russell B. Sugarmon talks about his early life and recounts his prolific political career. He describes his early work reorganizing the previously weak Shelby County Democratic Club, his legal defense of demonstrators arrested during sit-ins, and his famous campaign to run for County Commissioner in 1959.

element.name: none
element.field: Russell Sugarmon Jr., Memphis lawyer and judge, 2000

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview with Charles "Emmie Lee" Wadlington, whose husband's family developed the Evergreen Subdivision. She talks about who local streets are named after, how Natch the bear started the Memphis Zoo, and who owned businesses. Futhermore, she discusses how the neighborhood changed as she grew up.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Charles "Emmie Lee" Wadlington, wife of Evergreen developer, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with James Hunter Lane Jr., former Public Works Commissioner and City Councilman, he recounts the proccess of desegregating Memphis and his own evolving political idealogyï¿½in relation to African Americans during the 1950s and 1960s.

element.name: none
element.field: Hunter Lane Jr., Public Works Commissioner and City Councilman, June 2004

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, Downing Pryor describes being the first President of the City Council in 1968 and how the new, inexperienced City Council struggled to excercize authority and put an end to the Sanitation Worker's Strike. He also recounts the King assassination and how it caused African American leadership to fragment in the city of Memphis.

element.name: none
element.field: Downing Pryor, first President of the City Council, 1982

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, former Public Works Commissioner and City Councilman James Lane Jr. describes the political tension within the cabinets of Shelby county government leading up to and following the Sanitation Worker's Strike and the assassination of Dr. King in 1968, as well as his own evolving views on the Civil Rights movement.

element.name: none
element.field: Hunter Lane Jr., Public Works Commissioner and City Councilman, July 2004

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, Reverend at Beale Street Baptist Church James A. Jordan describes his participation at the Minister's March following the death of Martin Luther King and his work with Jim Lawson of the SCLC. He discusses the tension of trying to prevent unnecessary violence from breaking out in the African American community.

element.name: none
element.field: Rev. James Jordan, Beale Street Baptist Church, 1982

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview with Kay Portman, President of the Mid-Memphis Improvement Association. She talks about the history of the association, housing conditions in Midtown, and expressway construction.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Citizens to Preserve Overton Park v. Volpe

element.name: none
element.field: Here, interviewee and former Shelby County Commissioner Vasco Smith describes his long political career and his time as President of the Shelby County Democratic Club . He also talks about his support for his wife, Maxine Smith, and her exceptional Civil Rights work throughout her own career as the Memphis NAACP Executive Secretary.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with Fred Davis, founding member and treasurer of the Shelby Country Democratic Club, he recounts his efforts to organize African-American communities to assist the Ray Sugarmon campaign and other important local elections. He also describes his work with the NAACP, various protest and sit-in experiences, and how religion and music influence himself and his community.

element.name: none
element.field: Fred Davis, Shelby Country Democratic Club, 2000

element.name: none
element.field: Here, interviewee and Memphian Roscoe Dixon talks about his work with Operation Push in the 1970's, and the changing trends he sees in the Civil Rights Movement and African American communities since the death of Dr. King. He explains how the Great Society Programs opened educational opportunities to some African American Memphians for the first time.

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Bill and Vicki Webber, residents of the Hyde Park area. They mention the strong sense of community two civic organizations, Hyde Park Garden Club and Hyde Park Civic Association, brought to the neighborhood. The Webbers sold their house in Hyde Park to the first black family in the neighborhood, they recall neighbors' reaction to the desegregation of the area. This interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. element.name: en_US
element.field: Bill and Vicki Webber, Hyde Park residents, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Mina and Bill Chase, both who discussed the early land development of North Parkway and home development in the area. Mina and Bill both discuss the change from country roads to paved streets and the early subdivisions of the area. Mina also mentions early schools and churches in the nearby neighborhoods. This interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Mina and Bill Chase, Vollintine Evergreen residents, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Here interviewee Samuel B. Hollis, General Executive Assistant to Mayor Edmund Orgill and friend to the Good Government League, describes the difficulties of operating in the power vacuum created after the death of E.H. Crump. He also talks about how the status quo reinforces inequality and continues to shape politics in Memphis

element.name: none
element.field: Samuel Hollis, General Executive Assistant to Mayor Edmund Orgill, 2004

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Sarah Booth White, longtime resident of Hein Park. White talks about the layout of the neighborhood and the difference between home owners and renters in the area. She also mentions the garden club, civic club, and what she thinks the reaction will be when the first black family moves in on the street. White also discusses the churches and schools in the area and their impact. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Sarah Booth White, longtime resident of Hein Park, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with William Norris Jr., the former Sheriff of Shelby County, describes how he integrated his Deputies and his activism during the Sanitation Workers Strike starting in 1967. He also discusses the current problems he sees in race relations in Memphis and what he believes ought to be done to ease these tensions.

element.name: none
element.field: William Norris Jr., Sheriff of Shelby County, 2004

element.name: none
element.field: In this interviewï¿½Camille Sparks discusses her life in Midtown, Memphis. She talks about her family, how they moved around a lot, and her neighbors. She also describes what Midtown looked likeï¿½before she left in 1944.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Joe Sohm, resident of the VECA neighborhood, real estate agent, and alumni of Southwestern. Sohm moved to the neighborhood during a time of racial unrest but says it has stabilized. The involvement VECA had in dealing with blockbusting and bringing people together. Sohm talks about his real estate work and the people that contact him looking to live in the Southwestern Community. This interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Joe Sohm, Southwestern alumnus and real estate agent, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Nell S. Aspero, a long time native of Memphian who was heavily involved in the Vollintine Evergreen community. Aspero lived in the neighborhood since her childhood and attended Snowden Middle School and Trinity Methodist Church, two long time institutions of the community. She discusses many of the small businesses that have been in the area and the change Rhodes College, known then as Southwestern, made in the development of the neighborhood. She also discusses her time practicing law and her experience working with E.H. Crump. This interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Alice Hanley, former student of Snowden School and longtime resident of Overton neighborhood. Hanley's children also went to Snowden, she discusses the many changes the school and neighborhood has been through. Hanley also mentions the civic clubs and garden clubs that existed in the area, mainly the Hein Park Garden Club. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Alice Hanley, former Snowden School student, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, Memphian Johnnie Mae Peters describes her long term cooperation and work with H.T. Lockard, the NAACP, the SCDC, and Sheriff William Norris. She recounts life in Memphis before desegregation and her work organizing sit-ins, protests, and the registration of voters.

element.name: none
element.field: Johnnie Mae Peters, Civil Rights activist, 2004

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Joe Hough, lifelong member of the VECA neighborhood and active member of the neighborhood association. Hough talks about the changing demographics of the neighborhood and its effects on the real estate market. He discusses block-busting, red lining, and white flight. He also gives a brief history of the VECA Neighborhood Association. This interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Joe Hough, lifelong Vollintine Evergreen resident, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Donald Coffey, principal of Snowden School, which consisted of elementary and junior high. Coffey explains the layout of the school, how many students are from the neighborhood and how many are bused and goes in depth about the initiation and continuation of the schools optional program. He discusses a brief history of the school and its involvement with the community. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Donald Coffey, former Snowden School Principal, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with former Shelby County Commissioner and President of the SCDC Vasco Smith, he talks about the creation of the Memphis Community Relations Committee, the organization of sit-ins and protests, and instances of apathy, intimidation, and violence against demonstrators.

element.name: none
element.field: Pat Fawdry and Betty Tilley interview Miss Margaret Johnson and Miss Frances Johnson about growing up in Memphis around the turn of the century. The two ladies disuss how the neighborhood developed over time and what they think about its progression since then. Funded by the Tennessee Committee for the Humanities.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: Here, interviewee Reverend Henry L. Starks describes what it was like living in segregated Memphis as an African American man and the divide between white and black religious leaders that continued past the height of the Civil Rights Movement.

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview with Jeff A Marmon Jr. He grew up in the Evergreen neighborhood and spent most of his life there. He saw the Evergreen neighborhood start to develop businesses within the community. Jeff also recalls some of the people who lived in the Evergreen neighborhood when he was younger.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, son of Memphis Mayor (1960-1963, 1968-1971) Henry Loeb, Henry G. Loeb Jr. recounts his father's time as mayor in the late 1960s and gives insight to his point of view. He provides insight to his father's controversial stances on the 1968 Sanitation Worker's Strike and recalls his father's turbulent political and business careers until his stroke in 1988.

element.name: none
element.field: Henry Loeb Jr., son of Memphis Mayor, 2004

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with Maxine Smith, Executive Secretary of the Memphis NAACP from 1962 to 1965 and the first African American person on the Memphis Board of Education, she discusses the role of women's groups in the Civil Rights movement and what ought to be done to bolster economic growth in African American communities.

element.name: none
element.field: Maxine Smith, Executive Secretary of the Memphis NAACP, 1982

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Irving Sachrit, member of the Vollintine-Evergreen neighborhood. Sachrit discusses the many social changes that happened during the period of desegregation. She mentions white flight, block-busting, and the integration of the neighborhood churches. Sachrit also talks about how locally owned businesses are affected by chain stores, and how that has affected her neighborhood. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Modeane Thompson, a social worker, counselor, and longtime resident of the VECA neighborhood. Thompson recalls being among the first black families to become involved in VECA and attend Little Flower church and school. She also mentions the block club started on her street, University Park Community Association. Thompson talks about the community developments in the area and how they are focusing on white streets in the neighborhood and ignoring the bordering black streets. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Modeane Thompson, social worker and counselor, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, attorney and former congressman Russell Sugarmon Jr recounts his famous 1959 campaign for Public Works Commissioner for Memphis, his work with the Shelby County Democratic Club, and how important it was for securing aid and helping push legislation that benefited the African American community.

element.name: none
element.field: Russell Sugarmon Jr., Memphis lawyer and judge, June 2004

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Dr. Peyton Rhodes, President Emeritus of Southwestern at Memphis. Rhodes tells his story of moving to and settling in Memphis as well as Southwesternï¿½s start in Memphis. He explains the development of Southwestern's campus and gives a brief history of the buildings and the people involved. Rhodes discusses the school's integration and the racial layout of the student body and faculty. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Dr. Peyton Rhodes, President Emeritus of Southwestern at Memphis, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Here, Ronald Walter recalls becoming Chief Administrative Assistant to congressman Harold Ford between 1977 and 1981 and how being African American influenced the political strategies carried out by Senator Ford. He also discusses the forms of discrimination from both within and without the African American community, and how economic development is the key to progressing civil rights.

element.name: none
element.field: Ronald Walter, Chief Administrative Assistant to congressman Harold Ford, 1983

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Judge Harry Wellford, longtime resident of the Vollintine Evergreen neighborhood. Wellford talks about the area and prominent families in it before major land development. He mentions the development of Southwestern in the community, the architecture and the changes it brought. Wellford also discusses the race relations and stabilization of the community. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Judge Harry Wellford, Vollintine Evergreen resident, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with Rabbi James Wax he talks about the work done by the Memphis Committee for Community Relations and the Ministry Alliance. In both of these organizations, Wax and other religious leaders of various faiths collaborated in order to help progress the Civil Rights Movement.

element.name: none
element.field: Rabbi James Wax, Civil Rights leader, 1983

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Rick Thomas, a professor of sociology at Southwestern and resident of the VECA neighborhood. He talks about how the ethnic characteristics and age composition of the neighborhood has changed over the years. Thomas also goes into the story of how VECA, Vollintine Evergreen Community Association, came to be and their role in the neighborhood. He attributes the stability of the neighborhood not only to VECA but to the small locally owned shops in the area. This interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Rick Thomas, a professor of sociology at Southwestern, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Here, Tennessee attorney Thomas R. Prewitt Sr. recounts representing the city of Memphis in Watson v. Memphis and the extreme tension of the late 1960s. He also talks about what he sees as the failure of the local and federal government to make proactive legislation that would aid the African American community.

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with George Brown, an attorney and a representative on the Memphis City School Board. Brown and his family were one of the first black households on his street in the Vollintine-Evergreen community. He talks about the changing complexion of the neighborhood and the ever-changing boundaries of the VECA neighborhood. Brown mentions community churches and some of their impact and programs. this interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: George Brown, attorney and Memphis City School Board rep., 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with Maxine Smith, Executive Secretary of the Memphis NAACP from 1962 to 1965 and the first African American person on the Memphis Board of Education, she talks about her work with the NAACP starting in the early 1950s and the difficulties of living in segregated Memphis. She also discusses her voter registration work and the push-back from segregationists throughout the 1950s and 1960s.

element.name: none
element.field: Maxine Smith, Executive Secretary of the Memphis NAACP, 2000

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, prolific Memphis lawyer and judge Russell B. Sugarmon Jr. describes his political career following his campaign for Memphis Public Works Commission in 1959. Despite its failure, Russell Sugarmon's campaign was the first effort of African American voters to nearly put a representative in office, and served to further unify and strengthen the resolve of groups like the NAACP and SCDC.

element.name: none
element.field: Russel Sugarmon Jr., Memphis lawyer and judge, July 2004

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, native Memphian and lawyer Lewis R. Donelson III describes the challenges of forming a stronger Republican Party in Memphis during and after the Crump era. He also shares how he believes the support of African Americans influenced the shifting political sphere of Memphis in the late 1960s and 1970s.

element.name: none
element.field: Lewis Donelson, native Memphian and lawyer, 2004

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Dorothy Bilsky, a former teacher who talks about the school system during the time of desegregation. She discusses the court ordered transition for teachers during desegregation and her experience teaching at a majority black school. She also mentions the cultural competency issues between many of the white teachers that were transferred to majority black schools. Bilsky taught at Cypress Junior High and this interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: Here, Lillie Wheeler Jones recounts her "grassroots" campaign work in coordination with the NAACP and SCDC for Russell Sugarmon's run for Commissioner and later for President John F. Kennedy. She describes how direct community contact was the most effective means of forming a cohesive political front and how leadership in the African American community ought to be accessible.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview Jessie Perkins describes what the Evergreen neighborhood was like when she moved there in 1911. ï¿½She talks about different social organizations, the Evergreen Civic Club for examample; what she did for fun; and where she did it. She also discusses how the Evergreen community has changed.

element.name: none

element.name: none
element.field: Here, interviewee Reverend Samuel Kyles recounts his work with People United to Save Humanity (PUSH) during the 1960s. He also talks about the effectiveness of boycotts and strikes both in the past and present for creating change.

element.name: none
element.field: Rev. Samuel Billy Kyles, People United to Save Humanity (PUSH), 1982

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Silvio Joseph Bosi who has lived in the Vollentine-Evergreen neighborhood his entire life. He mentions his life growing up in the area and about the grocery store his mother, an Italian immigrant, owned. Bosi then goes on to explain how he got his own grocery store and its own history. He discusses the Italian community and civic clubs in the neighborhood. This interview was conducted in 1979

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. element.name: en_US
element.field: Silvio Joseph Bosi, immigrant and grocery store owner, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Here, interviewee Charles "Charlie" S. Peete, program director for the Memphis Dutch Treat Luncheon, discusses his long time friendship and volunteer work for Henry Loeb for several decades spanning his years as Commissioner and Mayor. He largely defends Henry Loeb's policies and explains how and why other Memphis Conservatives have changed ideologically since the 1960s.

element.name: none
element.field: Charlie Peete Jr., Memphis Dutch Treat Luncheon, 2004

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview John Ford Canale, a Southwestern alumnus, shares stories of living in the Evergreen neighborhood and in Memphis in general. He talks about his neighboors, how the neigborhood has been kept up, and freeway construction.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Citizens to Preserve Overton Park v. Volpe

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Gilbert Delugach, whose family took part in the land and home development of the VECA neighborhood. Delugach gives details on the neighborhood's steady development from the late 20's up until the depression, then a spike again from 1938-1941. He also discusses the architecture and styles of the houses built in this time. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. element.name: en_US
element.field: Gilbert Delugach, Vollintine Evergreen neighborhood developer, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, East Memphian John Fisher recounts his activism and experiences in the early 1960's as well as his later coordination with Jim Lawson and other Civil Rights leaders through his connections with St. Mary's Cathedral, including the highly spontaneous "Memphis Cares" demonstration in Crump Stadium.

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview of Miss Annah Lee Early. Early tells the story of her church's history, which later becomes Evergreen Presbyterian Church. She also discusses the experiences she encountered in the church, and current race relations and community service at Evergreen Presbyterian.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Annah Early, member of Evergreen Presbyterian Church, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with Walter P. Armstrong Jr, president of the Board of Education of the Memphis City Schools from 1956 to 1961, Armstrong recalls an NAACP lawsuit against segregation and the impact that the Sanitation Workers' Strike had on the climate of race relationships in Memphis.

element.name: none
element.field: Walter Armstrong, Board of Education President, 1982

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, President of Memphis NAACP William Johnson discusses how the NAACP seeks to work with other organizations like the National League and PUSH. He also speaks on the difficulties of progressing the movement in the face of more subtle, yet thoroughly ingrained racial inequality.

element.name: none
element.field: William Johnson, President of Memphis NAACP, 1982

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview of Mrs. Robert K. Williams. Mrs. Williams speaks on her life and the development of her neighborhood. She extensively mentions the expressway that was planned to be built and the effects from it on her neighborhood. She also elaborates on her life growing up and the multiple changes in the neighborhood since she was young.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. element.name: en_US
element.field: Citizens to Preserve Overton Park v. Volpe

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Linda Terry Vaughan and Lorena Terry Quick, two longtime residents of the area who recall time before the boost in land development. The two sisters recall farm life and a neighborhood golf course their father opened. Linda Vaughan attended Rhodes College, formerly known as Southwestern, and talks about the development there and her time at the college. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. element.name: en_US
element.field: Linda Terry Vaughan and Lorena Terry Quick, longtime Vollintine Evergreen residents, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Margaret Dichtel, the first president of the VECA organization. Dichtel gives a history of the Little Flower Church, a prominent and long-standing church in the Vollintine-Evergreen Community. She also discusses the impact the Jewish community had on the neighborhood. Ditchel mentions the changing demographics due to white flight and the outcomes it has had on the neighborhood schools. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none

Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview with Jim Wood, a longtime resident of the Evergreen neighboorhood in Memphis. He moved from Arkansas in 1922 to work for a cement company. He talks about living in Memphis, discussing housing, infrastucture, and commutes.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, native Memphian Thomas "Pete" Sisson recounts his long political career starting in the Public Parks Commission, being president of the Memphis Jaycee Club, and his role as Public Works Commissioner throughout the 1950s and 1960s.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview that was conducted sometime in the late-1970s, Pat Faudry and Bena Cates interview Mrs. Virigina Busby. ï¿½Speaking of both the past and present, Mrs. Busby describes the Evergreen Community and Memphis in general.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. element.name: none
element.field: Here Anne Shafer, Head of the League of Women Voters from 1958 to 1961, describes her political work and Civil Rights activism from the mid to late 1960s. A devout Catholic, she talks about organizing members of the church in the Catholic Human Relations Council and overcoming the conservative push-back within the clergy.

element.name: none
element.field: Anne Shafer, Head of the League of Women Voters, 2004

element.name: none
element.field: Here, interviewee Jimmie Wall Farris talks about the political careers of herself and her husband, William "Bill" Farris, that started in Memphis in the late 1950s. She describes how their positions on the Democratic National Committee and the controversies surrounding the 1959 election of Memphis Public Works Commissioner.

element.name: none
element.field: This interview with Mr. Sam Seessel is a part of the Everett R. Cook Collection and was conducted by MIFA. Mr. Seessel is a long time resident of the Evergreen area, and speaks of his experiences growing up there.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, H.T. Lockard describes the political maneuvering of the Memphis Democratic Party from the early 1950s through the 1960s. He recounts the large roll played by the Shelby County Democratic Club in organizing and registering voters, as well as its splinter organizations, the Tennessee Voters Council and Ninth District Democratic Club.

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview with Reverend David Hilliard in which he talks about his childhood experiences in Memphis. He also discusses what it was like returning back to Memphis after leaving.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, Memphis attorney and conservationist Lucius E. Burch Jr. discusses the historical patterns that influenced the Civil Rights movement in Memphis, and what he believes ought to be done to counteract the effects of racism in America.

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Berta B Radford, a longtime member of the Vollintine Evergreen community. Radford talks about her move to the Memphis, and her street before home development picked up. She mentions the racial shifts in the neighborhoods around her, although she feels her street has been very stable with little white flight or changes. Radford also discusses a few of the neighborhood businesses and development of the subdivisions. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, Helen G. Wax describes her and her husband Rabbi James Wax's activism work during the 1950s. She recounts how she helped organize and implement the Fund for Needy Children and the work that many members of the Memphis Jewish community did in the Civil Rights Movement.

element.name: none
element.field: Helen Wax, Fund for Needy Children, 2004

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Polk Agee, the oldest practicing architect in Tennessee. Mr. Algee discusses his many architecture ventures in the Memphis area and explains the various styles he's worked with. In this interview Algee also mentions the demographics of the neighborhoods he has designed houses for. The interview was conducted in 1979.ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview conducted by Metropolitan Inter-Faith Association (MIFA) with A.W. Willis about the Vollintine Evergreen Community.

element.name: none

element.field: A.W. Willis, civil rights lawyer and Memphis businessman, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Former "Invader" Colby Smith describes his time at Southwestern University and his tangential work with the NAACP and Democratic Club. He also also talks about his idealogical devide with many moderate Civil Rights leaders and explains the thinking of African American "militant" groups in the 1960s.

element.name: none
element.field: Coby Smith, Invader and Southwestern alum, 1983

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview done with Eleanor Richmond by the Mid-Memphis Improvement Association. In this interview Miss Richmond discusses her childhood growing up in Oxford, Mississippi, as well as her family history. Miss Richmond also discusses her time as a teacher and principal in Memphis Elementary Schools during segregation and integration.

element.name: none

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview Frances Rosenstein, a resident of the Evergreen neighborhood, talks about her past neighbors.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Ethel Terry and Eleanor Barham, two longtime community members of the Vollintine Evergreen community. In this interview they go into detail about the development of the community, from its transition from dirt roads to pavement to old farm land being sold to build houses, and eventually subdivisions. Also mentioned are various small businesses, pharmacies, groceries, and dairy services, that have been active in the neighborhood. ï¿½

element.name: none

element.name: en_US
element.field: Ethel Terry and Eleanor Barham, Vollintine Evergreen residents, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview Connie Star talks about living on Buena Vista in the Evergreen neighborhood. She shares stories of her neighbors and talks about what it was like living in Memphis in the first half of the 20th century.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. element.name: none
element.field: Here, H.T. Lockard talks about his time as President of the Memphis chapter of the NAACP between 1953 and 1957, setting up a legal defense fund for imprisoned Civil Rights protesters, becoming the cabinet member to Governor Buford Ellington, a consultant to Lyndon B. Johnson, and- finally- Shelby Country Criminal Court Judge from 1975 to 1994.ï¿½

element.name: none
element.field: H.T. Lockard, President of the Memphis NAACP, 2000

element.name: none
element.field: Here, Paul Tudor Jones describes the events that transpired during the Orgill administration, his work with the Urban League, and the activism of local religious leaders. He also describes how the Civil Rights movement of the 1960s is ultimately connected to other justice movements, and the continuing struggle of race relations.

element.name: none
element.field: Interviewee Josephine Burson recalls her position as State Commissioner of Employment Security starting in 1948, and her role on the Democratic Party Executive Committee. She reflects on how being an African American woman influenced her career in government.

element.name: none
element.field: Josephine Burson, State Commissioner of Employment Security, 2004

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview with Grace Rudisill-Holt, long time resident of Overton Park/Evergreen neighborhood. She talks about life in the neighborhood, including the opening of the Memphis Zoo and the construction of the freeway in the 60s.

element.name: none

element.field: Citizens to Preserve Overton Park v. Volpe

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Granville Davis, a professor at Rhodes College, formerly known as Southwestern. He talks about the influence VECA, Southwestern, and a nearby synagogue had on shaping and stabilizing the surrounding community throughout the years. Davis also mentions a brief history of Southwestern and the college's move to its current location off of North Parkway. This interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

element.field: Granville Davis, former Rhodes College faculty, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview, Dr. Jameson Jones talks about his career in Memphis. He started as the academic dean at Southwestern in 1955 and then became the president of the Memphis Academy of Arts in 1972. He discusses challenges faced by Mid-Memphis Improvement Association (MMIA) as well as life in Evergreen neighboorhood.

element.name: none

element.field: Jameson Jones, Academic Dean at Southwestern, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Charles and Jean Scruggs, two residents of the VECA neighborhood. The Scruggs talk about their experience as a black couple moving to the neighborhood during a transitional period of integration. They discuss their involvement in the VECA organization and how they dealt with white flight. The Scruggs also mention the positive and negative affects public policy has had on the surrounding area. This interview was conducted in 1979. ï¿½

element.name: en_US
element.field: Charles and Jean Scruggs, Vollintine Evergreen residents, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Alice Crump, who worked at the Crump Brothers Store, a general store that had been on Jackson for 70 years. She discusses Terrytown, a small community that formed before the official development of the Vollintine-Evergreen subdivision. Terrytown was self-sufficient and Alice Crump recalls the Terrytown school, cemetery, the general store, and a near-by church. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none

Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Any image from the library's collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center.

element.name: none
element.field: This is an interview with Charles F. Drake and Lucy Jane Collins. They talk about the Evergreen Community and the changes it experienced while growing up there. They also mention different locations and memories they have of Evergreen.

element.name: none
element.field: This item is made available with permission from the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Permission to reproduce or publish this item is required and may be subject to copyright or other legal restrictions imposed by parties outside of the Library. Please contact the History Department of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphislibrary.org to request permission. element.name: en_US
element.field: Charles Drake and Lucy Collins, Evergreen residents, 1979

element.name: none
element.field: Here, interviewee and Memphis native Jennie Betts talks about her time as a student activist, participating in sit-ins, and her work in the Russell Sugarmon campaign for Public Works Commissioner.

element.name: none
element.field: In this interview with Bill Farris, City Commissioner under Mayors Loeb and Ingram, Executive Assistant to Mayors Toby and Orgill and City Judge of Memphis, he describes the political pressures of democrats in the post-Crump era of the 1960s. He talks about appointing the first African American to head a board in the Memphis city government, Macy O'Walker, and how the city government sought to handle the Sanitation Worker's Strike of 1968.

element.name: none
element.field: Interview with Thomas Turley, a long-time resident of the VECA neighborhood. Turley mentions the many developments in the neighborhood and the how Southwestern has sped that whole process up. He also talks about the development of the Sears building in the Crosstown area. Turley talks about public policy, the good it's done for the neighborhood, and the drawbacks it has on Innercity neighborhoods. This interview was conducted in 1979.

element.name: none
element.field: Executive Secretary of Memphis NAACP from 1962 to 1995 Maxine Smith describes her extensive work with the NAACP and Shelby County Democratic Club. She recounts her upbringing in Memphis and encounters with leaders in the African American community and how these influenced her throughout her extensive career in activism.

element.name: none
element.field: Maxine Smith, Executive Secretary of the Memphis NAACP, 2004
